Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2010 10:50AM - edited Jul 21, 2010 10:54AM by ghostie You are not alone! Mine bothered me until the day I had it removed. I've always been disturbed by anything that gets under my skin, like splinters, so this was nightmarish to me. I did my best to ignore it, but I never succeeded in getting comfortable with it. It didn't help that it was "tilted" and one of the raised bumps on the surface was practically poking through my skin. And it also upset me that when I had it removed, they only used a local anesthetic so I had to feel all the disturbing sensations of tugging, etc., while they were removing it. (I asked them for something like Valium to help me relax a little and not be so anxious, but they refused and told me, "Oh, you'll be fine." I really, really hated the crew at that facility.) When I read about people who decide to just leave it in place when they're finished with chemo, I'm amazed. For your sake, I truly hope that you come to grips with your port more than I did with mine. But at least know that someone else out there feels your pain! Almost forgot to add, despite all this rant I am glad to have had a port versus the alternative. And if I had to do it again, I absolutely would. BTW, my husband thought that the entire process was very Matrix-like. To cheer me up, he would talk about my being "uploaded"!

Posts.Content: ghostie wrote: Been lurking for awhile. Started rads mid-April. It's fascinating that there are such varied creams/lotions recommendations. My center recommended something called RadX, but I had to order it online because none of the pharmacies carry it. Anyway, here is my little list of all the things I've now heard of being recommended: 1. 98% (or more) pure aloe vera gel 2. Aquafor 3. Calendula lotion 4. Bag balm 5. Udderly Smooth Udder Cream 6. RadX Radiation Therapy cream 7. Miaderm Radiation Relief And the things I've heard to avoid? 1. Products with oil 2. Products with alcohol 3. Products with heavy fragrance 4. All deodorants except Tom's or Arm & Hammer natural (no aluminum) So far, I've been putting on pure aloe immediately after rads, then I wait a minute for it to dry. Then I put the Udderly Smooth on. At night I use some Aquafor, and in the morning--before rads--I shower everything off, gently of course. This has been working well for me and I'm a very, very pale redhead who burns and freckles at the slightest bit of sun!
